awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Terrestrial Denitrification and Environmental Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitrogen is a vital plant nutrient, and its availability often limits tree growth. The microbial process of denitrification removes available nitrogen from ecosystems and produces a range of nitrogen gases, including nitrous oxide, a potent greenhouse gas. Earth system models often fail to capture the magnitude or global distribution of these nitrogen gas losses. Denitrification occurs under low-oxygen conditions, and measurements are complicated by both analytical challenges and tremendous spatial and temporal variation. This project will apply a suite of measurement approaches to test hypotheses about the way that several environmental factors regulate denitrification, and it will improve the representation of denitrification in an important earth system model. This research has important implications for policies regulating nitrogen as an air and water pollutant, and improvements to the earth system model support international science and policy programs for predicting future environmental change.

This project will advance understanding of the environmental regulation of denitrification in both field studies at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest in New Hampshire and as represented by the Community Land Model (CLM-CN). At Hubbard Brook, the project will test the role of several environmental factors hypothesized to regulate denitrification, including soil oxygen levels, soil depth, rainfall variability, soil warming, and soil acidification. The project will deploy measurement approaches that include soil core-based fluxes of nitrogen gases, continuous soil oxygen sensors, chamber-based gas fluxes, and nitrate stable isotopes. Together these measurements will provide a comprehensive assessment of denitrification and its environmental drivers, and will enable this project to improve representation of plant-microbe competition and carbon-nitrogen-oxygen biogeochemistry in the Community Land Model. The project will also train two graduate students and one postdoctoral associate, and it will offer hands-on biogeochemistry boot camps for diverse groups of graduate students on the advanced techniques used for measuring greenhouse gas emissions and related ecosystem processes.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The process of denitrification converts nitrate to nitrogen gases, including the potent greenhouse gas nitrous oxide (N2O) and elemental nitrogen (N2), while removing inorganic nitrogen from ecosystems and strengthening nitrogen limitation of plant growth. Despite its importance, this important process is poorly quantified in both field observations and model simulations. Measurements are hindered by technical challenges - especially for N2 - and by tremendous spatial and temporal variation in substrate availability (nitrate, organic carbon) and environmental conditions (oxygen level, temperature, moisture).

This project tested hypotheses about environmental regulation of N2 and N2O emissions from soils in response to major factors of environmental change at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest in New Hampshire, and it tested representation of nitrogen cycle dynamics in a leading Earth System Model (CLM-CN). This portion of this collaborative project characterized the magnitude and controls on N2 and N2O gas fluxes from Hubbard Brook soils. We measured how these N gas emissions varied in response to (1) oxygen concentration, (2) soil depth, (3) experimental drying and rewetting, and (4) experimental warming. We also installed high-frequency sensors to characterize variations in soil temperature, moisture, and oxygen concentration across soil depths and in response to experimental manipulations, and we contributed to testing CLM-CN with measurements of nitrogen cycle processes.

Our sensor measurements revealed that contrary to longstanding assumption, oxygen levels are not always high in the well-drained Spodosols of Hubbard Brook. Two of the three sites instrumented showed variable oxygen concentrations (0 to 20%) in the forest floor, and all three sites had period of low oxygen concentrations (< 2%) in deeper mineral soils (Bh and Bs horizons). The occurrence of these low-oxygen levels provides excellent conditions for denitrification and other biogeochemical processes. Our lab measurements showed that soil CO2 emissions decreased and N2 fluxes generally increased with increasing soil depth and oxygen level, while N2O emissions were variable. Combining lab and field sensor measurements showed that conditions conducive for sizeable N2 emissions occur far more regularly in these upland forest soils than commonly assumed. These results support the hypothesized importance of denitrification in subsurface mineral soils even in generally well-drained upland forest soils

We measured responses of N gas fluxes to three sets of field drought and rewetting experiments across the growing season. Drought treatments of 7-8 weeks each did not reduce soil moisture in early summer following heavy rain, but did reduce soil moisture in late summer and early fall. Droughted soils yielded higher concentrations of dissolved organic carbon, especially after rewetting. Experimental rewetting treatments increased soil moisture in the droughted soils, but did not reduce surface soil oxygen concentrations or consistently alter soil trace gas (CO2, N2O) emissions in the field. Lab-based gas measurements showed that N2 fluxes were large and variable and did not correspond with measured environmental variables, while N2O emissions corresponded with soil nitrate availability but not soil moisture or drought treatment. Field measurements of N2O emissions across topographic transects also varied with soil nitrate availability, and were consistently elevated in soil types characterized by mineral soils with well-developed spodic horizons that periodically saturate.

Lab-based warming experiments on soils collected from warmer (low-elevation) and cooler (high-elevation) sites in late summer (August) and at snowmelt (April), showed that neither N2O nor N2 fluxes responded to these variations in temperature, or to additions of water (summer) or nitrate (winter). N2 fluxes did not correspond with any measured variable, while summer N2O fluxes instead increased with soil nitrate availability.

Across these studies, N2 fluxes were generally 1-2 orders of magnitude larger than for N2O, highlighting its importance as a N loss pathway, particularly in deeper mineral soils periodically subject to low oxygen conditions. N2O emissions corresponded most with soil nitrate availability, and should decrease as inorganic nitrogen availability decreases in response to decreasing atmospheric nitrogen deposition and rising atmospheric CO2 concentrations.

 Broader Impacts

This portion of this project provided education and training in forest ecosystem ecology and biogeochemistry for five students and professionals (three women, two URM), including two Ph.D. students, one technician (now enrolled in a Ph.D. program), one REU student, and one undergraduate honors student.

More broadly, the project quantified difficult-to-measure nitrogen gas emissions and characterized their response to varying environmental conditions, including soil oxygen level, soil depth, drought/rewetting, and warming.  These measurements improve estimates of greenhouse gas emissions from soil and nitrogen loss fluxes from soil, as well as the representation of these processes in a widely used Earth System Model simulating future climate.
